Chapter One: The Process
1:51
Before we dive into actually designing the website, let's take a 30-foot view and talk about what the process looks
1:57
like. Now, there's actually two types of processes. The amateur process and the professional process. The amateur
2:03
process is basically taking a template and then customizing it to fit your or your client's need. The professional
2:08

2:16

Chapter Five: Development
1:48:18
Now that we have a nice static design, it's time to see how we're turning this into a real published website that
1:48:23
people can visit. Since I assume that you're new to web design, I'm going to give you a clear picture of how the
1:48:28
internet works so that you can understand how our new website is going to fit into the internet. So, how does
1:48:34
the internet work? Well, you're using a browser right now, something like Chrome or Safari. When you put in a URL like
1:48:41
Google.com, these letters, which we call a domain name, are being translated into numbers, something like 192.158.1.38.
1:48:52
Those numbers are called IP address. And much like your home address, it basically tells the browser where to go
1:48:57
and look for the website files. And where are they? Well, technically, if you want, you could link your domain to
1:49:04
your own computer, but for many reasons, we usually don't want to do this, right? You don't want your computer to or your
1:49:10
website to be down every time you close your computer. So, usually you would pay a service provider uh which we call a
1:49:16
hosting platform to host your files somewhere in the cloud. Now what are those files? Well, the core of every
1:49:23

1:24:12
heavy and we have two types of symmetry symmetrical and asymmetrical symmetrical
1:24:17

1:24:24
elements on each side but arranges them in a way that still feels balanced and Visually
1:24:30
pleasing so let me give you an example of each right so for symmetrical balance

1:24:42
image of another product below these images there are two blocks of text with descriptions of the products align
1:24:49
perfectly under the image this creates a mirror like effect making the design look formal balanced and for a
1:24:55
symmetrical balance imagine a seaw with a large child on one end and two smaller
1:25:01
children on the other right even though the children are different sizes the Seesaw can still balance on a web page
1:25:08
you might have a large image on one side and several smaller images or blocks of text on the other side the different
1:25:14
elements balance each other out visually the second principle is variety and variety involves using different shapes
1:25:20
colors and sizes to create interest in a design it prevents the design from being too monotonous and keeps the viewer
1:25:27
engaged for example a website for a children's toy store uses a mix of bright colors different fonts and
1:25:34
various playful shapes to keep the design Lively and engaging this variety keeps the user interested and
1:25:40
entertained while browsing the site number three is contrast contrast is about making elements Stand Out by using
1:25:47
differences in color size and shape high contrast makes text easier to read and
1:25:53
important information more noticeable helping to draw the viewer's attention to key parts of the design for example
1:25:59
on a News website headlines are often in a bold black text on a white background
1:26:04
and this high contrast makes the headline stand out and easy to read drawing attention to the most important
1:26:11
information first number four is alignment alignment means lining up elements to keep the design need and
1:26:17
orderly this can be along the edges or in the center ensuring that everything looks well organized and professional
1:26:23
for for example a professional portfolio site might align all text to the left and ensure all images are also aligned
1:26:30
along a common Edge this alignment creates a clean and organized look making the content easier to follow the
1:26:38
fifth principle is movement movement guides the viewer side through the design it helps direct attention to
1:26:43
important areas by creating a visual flow making the design feel Dynamic and engaging for example on a fashion block
1:26:51
movement can be created by arranging elements to guide the reads eye from a
1:26:56
large e catching image at the top down through the content with smaller images and text leading to the call to action
1:27:02
at the bottom the next one is a scale scale refers to the size of elements in relation to each other using different
1:27:09
sizes can show which elements are most important and create a sense of hierarchy in the design for example an architecture studi
1:27:17

5:22:41
have one you will learn how a style guide helps ensure consistency efficiency and a strong brand identity
5:22:47
in web design by the end of this lesson you will understand the key elements of a style guide and the benefits it brings
5:22:54
to your projects so what is a style guide a style guide is a detailed document that explains the design
5:23:00
standards and guidelines for a website or application it serves as a reference
5:23:05
tool for designers developers and content creators making sure that everything looks and works consistently
5:23:12
a style guide usually includes information about the brand identity such as how to use the logo the color
5:23:18
palette the typography and icons it also outlines design principles like layout
5:23:23
grids spacing and Alignment rules additionally it includes guidelines for user interface components
5:23:30
such as buttons forms and navigation bars as well as content guidelines for tone of voice grammar and formatting
5:23:36
standards lastly it pro provides instructions on how to use media like images and
5:23:42
videos so why it's important to have a style guide having a style guide is crucial for several reasons first it
5:23:48
ensures consistency across all elements of the website or application making everything look and feel more cohesive
5:23:55
this consistency builds trust with users and enhances their experience second a style guide helps teams work more
5:24:01
efficiently with clear guidelines designers and developers don't have to make decisions on the Fly reducing the
5:24:08
time spent on revisions and speeding up the project completion third a style guide helps maintain a strong and
5:24:14
recognizable brand identity by following the predefined standards every piece of content reinforces the Brand's image and
5:24:20
message fourth it promotes better collaboration among team members it acts
5:24:25
as a common reference point making it easier for new team members to understand and follow the established
5:24:31
design practices fifth a style guide helps maintain high quality output by adhering
5:24:38
to the guidelines the final product is more likely to be polished and professional six it ensures scalability
5:24:45
as the website or application grows a style guide helps new features and Pages align with the existing design which is
5:24:51
crucial for long-term maintenance and expansion and finally a consistent design makes it easier for users to
5:24:57
navigate and interact with the website a familiar look and feel enhances usability and overall
5:25:03
satisfaction you can find the style guide for this website here in this
5:25:12

What is a responsive website?
4:32:54
websites. And I want to start by telling you a short story. Uh in the early days
4:33:00
of the internet, meaning late '9s, early 2000s, all websites were nonresponsive,
4:33:08

4:33:13

4:33:20

4:33:30

4:33:35

4:33:40
small devices had problems displaying websites properly because websites were
4:33:45

4:33:51

4:33:58

4:34:04

4:34:12

4:34:18

4:34:24

4:34:39

4:34:45

4:34:52

4:34:57

4:35:03

4:35:16
